segments.text: was just terrifying to be honest and so we only had two weeks off the year there's no off-season in swimming it is literally all in and i got to you don't get to do the part that you love which for me is high caliber racing twice a year so there's a long time doing all the other you know 24 7 full invested components to get to the part that you absolutely love so for me i was living up and down and i was training in melbourne at the amco and i realized the 2006 commonwealth games were coming up in that same pool that i just swam in and 2006 after the commonwealth games i was in training sitting up and down and i had this light bulb moment where i started to take stock of my achievements and i realized for the very first time that i was proud of myself i'd never thought about it like that i'd never really taken stock of what had happened because

text:
Because all of your life is taken up with that achievement in the pool and you're really high achieving. Then what was it like then to step away from such a spectacularly successful career at the age of 23? This is your first career, your first switch. What was that like? What led you to that moment? How'd you know? It's quite extraordinary. Everyone wants to know from an athlete, when do you know when it's time to pull up? And it's only now that I look back and I wonder if it'd be different if times were different only because in that day, like I retired in 2006 and it's now 23, but I was mentally exhausted. I was burnt out. And back then, if you were burnt out, you retired. There was no chance for a mental health break. There was no chance to have a long break out of the pool. Our coaches believed that for every week that you spent out of the pool was three weeks it took to get back to where you were before that week. So taking a break was just.
was just terrifying to be honest and so we only had two weeks off the year there's no off-season in swimming it is literally all in and i got to you don't get to do the part that you love which for me is high caliber racing twice a year so there's a long time doing all the other you know 24 7 full invested components to get to the part that you absolutely love so for me i was living up and down and i was training in melbourne at the amco and i realized the 2006 commonwealth games were coming up in that same pool that i just swam in and 2006 after the commonwealth games i was in training sitting up and down and i had this light bulb moment where i started to take stock of my achievements and i realized for the very first time that i was proud of myself i'd never thought about it like that i'd never really taken stock of what had happened because
When you're in that mindset of what's next, life just has this incredible feeling and it becomes another.
